DataSource.ScriptBody:
Option Explicit
SetLocale("en-us")
Dim SourceID : SourceId = WScript.Arguments(0) Dim ManagedEntityId : ManagedEntityId = WScript.Arguments(1) Dim ComputerIdentity : ComputerIdentity = WScript.Arguments(2)
Dim oAPI : Set oAPI = CreateObject("MOM.ScriptAPI") Dim oDiscoveryData : Set oDiscoveryData = oAPI.CreateDiscoveryData(0, SourceId, ManagedEntityId)
if IsServiceEnabled() Then Dim oInst : Set oInst = oDiscoveryData.CreateClassInstance("$MPElement[Name='Microsoft.SystemCenter.Apm.ActivatedApmAgent']$") Call oInst.AddProperty("$MPElement[Name='Windows!Microsoft.Windows.Computer']/PrincipalName$", ComputerIdentity) Call oInst.AddProperty("$MPElement[Name='System!System.Entity']/DisplayName$", ComputerIdentity)
Call oDiscoveryData.AddInstance(oInst) End If
Call oAPI.Return(oDiscoveryData)
Function IsServiceEnabled() IsServiceEnabled = false Dim WShell : Set WShell = CreateObject("wscript.shell") Dim s : s = WShell.RegRead("HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services\System Center Management APM\Start") if 4 <> s Then 'Service disabled state = 4 IsServiceEnabled = true End If End Function

WriteAction.ScriptBody:
Option Explicit
SetLocale("en-us")
Const commandLine = "%windir%\system32\inetsrv\appcmd.exe list apppools /xml"
Dim WShell : Set WShell = CreateObject("wscript.shell") Dim oExec : Set oExec = WShell.Exec(commandLine)
If Not oExec.StdOut.AtEndOfStream Then Dim stdOutput : stdOutput = "" & oExec.StdOut.ReadAll() End If Dim execResult : execResult = oExec.ExitCode
' Write error output and exit if result is not 0 If 0 <> execResult Then Wscript.StdErr.Write stdOutput Wscript.Quit execResult Else Dim objXMLDoc : Set objXMLDoc = CreateObject("Microsoft.XMLDOM") objXMLDoc.loadXml(stdOutput)
Dim xPath : xPath = "appcmd/APPPOOL" Dim xmlNodes : Set xmlNodes = objXMLDoc.getElementsByTagName(xPath)
Dim apppool
For each apppool in xmlNodes
Dim appPoolState : appPoolState = UCase(apppool.Attributes.getNamedItem("state").text) Dim appName : appName = apppool.Attributes.getNamedItem("APPPOOL.NAME").text
If(appPoolState = "STARTED") Then
Dim commandLineR : commandLineR = "%windir%\system32\inetsrv\appcmd.exe recycle apppool """ & appName & """" Dim oExecR : Set oExecR = WShell.Exec(commandLineR)
Dim stdOutputR : stdOutputR = "" If Not oExecR.StdOut.AtEndOfStream Then stdOutputR = oExecR.StdOut.ReadAll() End If execResult = oExecR.ExitCode
' Write error output and exit if result is not 0 If 0 <> execResult Then Wscript.StdErr.Write stdOutputR Wscript.Quit execResult Else Wscript.StdOut.Write stdOutputR End If End If Next End If
Dim oAPI : Set oAPI = CreateObject("MOM.ScriptAPI") Call oAPI.LogScriptEvent("ActivatedApmAgent.RecycleIIS.Task.vbs", 3201, 0, "Recycle Application Pools task done.")
Wscript.Quit execResult
On Error Resume Next Wscript.StdErr.Write Err.Description Wscript.Quit Err.Code

Option Explicit
SetLocale("en-us")
Const commandLine = "%WINDIR%\SYSTEM32\IISRESET.EXE /RESTART"
Dim WShell : Set WShell = CreateObject("wscript.shell") Dim oExec : Set oExec = WShell.Exec(commandLine) Do While oExec.Status = 0 WScript.Sleep 100 Loop
If Not oExec.StdOut.AtEndOfStream Then Dim stdOutput : stdOutput = "" & oExec.StdOut.ReadAll() End If Dim execResult : execResult = oExec.ExitCode
' Write error output and exit if result is not 0 If 0 <> execResult Then Wscript.StdErr.Write stdOutput Wscript.Quit execResult End If
Dim oAPI : Set oAPI = CreateObject("MOM.ScriptAPI") Call oAPI.LogScriptEvent("ActivatedApmAgent.RestartIIS.Task.vbs", 3202, 0, "Restart IIS task done.")
Wscript.StdOut.Write stdOutput Wscript.Quit execResult
On Error Resume Next Wscript.StdErr.Write Err.Description Wscript.Quit Err.Code

File.Name: RestartIntercept.cmd
File.Contents:
@echo off
net stop %1 IF errorlevel 2 goto :Success IF errorlevel 1 goto :Error
sc query %1 | find "STATE" | find "STOPPED" IF errorlevel 1 goto :Running
IF errorlevel 0 net start %1 IF errorlevel 0 goto :Success goto :Error
:Error exit /B 1
:Success exit /B 0
:Running echo The %1 service has been automatically started. exit /B 0

DisplayString.Name: Activated APM Agent
DisplayString.Description: Activated APM Agent

DisplayString.Name: Activated APM Agent DataSource
DisplayString.Description: Activated APM Agent DataSource

DisplayString.Name: Interval Seconds
DisplayString.Description: Interval Seconds

DisplayString.Name: Activated APM Agent Properties DataSource
DisplayString.Description: Activated APM Agent Properties DataSource

DisplayString.Name: Interval Seconds
DisplayString.Description: Interval Seconds

DisplayString.Name: Timeout Seconds
DisplayString.Description: Timeout Seconds

DisplayString.Name: Discovery of Activated .NET APM Agent
DisplayString.Description: Discovery of Activated .NET APM Agent

DisplayString.Name: Discovery of Activated .NET APM Agent Properties
DisplayString.Description: Discovery of Activated .NET APM Agent Properties

DisplayString.Name: APM .NET Server-Side Monitoring Configuration
DisplayString.Description: This monitor verifies that an APM Agent has been correctly processing APM .NET server-side monitoring configuration. The monitor turns to a warning state when an invalid configuration or a configuration conflict is detected.

DisplayString.Name: APM .NET Server-Side monitoring Configuration Error or Conflict
DisplayString.Description: The APM Agent has encountered an error while processing APM .NET Server-Side monitoring configuration. This could be caused by an agent problem or by incorrect or conflicting configuration or thresholds specified in multiple templates for the same application.

DisplayString.Name: APM .NET Object Discovery
DisplayString.Description: This monitor verifies that the Management Server has successfully created objects that are needed for APM monitoring. The monitor turns to a warning state when a failure occurs during APM objects discovery, as this will prevent configuration from being distributed to agents. The monitor resets to Healthy when object discovery succeeds.

DisplayString.Name: Failed to Generate Objects needed for APM monitoring
Successfully Generated Objects needed for APM monitoring
Management Server Failed to Generate Objects needed for APM monitoring
DisplayString.Description: Management Server Failed to Generate Objects needed for APM monitoring to be distributed to agents.

DisplayString.Name: AVIcode Enterprise Agent and APM Agent have been deployed to the same machine
DisplayString.Description: This monitor verifies that an AVIcode .NET Enterprise Agent has not been installed on a computer where the System Center Operations Manager APM feature had already been installed.

DisplayString.Name: AVIcode agent is found on a machine that was already running the System Center Operations Manager APM service
DisplayString.Description: The AVIcode .NET Enterprise Agent should only be deployed to servers that do not have the System Center Operations Manager APM service installed. The two services are incompatible and should not be running side by side. This agent is now in a non supported state.

DisplayString.Name: APM DataSource Availability
DisplayString.Description: This monitor checks that the APM DataSource is able to communicate with the APM Service.

DisplayString.Name: APM DataSource Connected to APM Service
APM DataSource is not able to communicate with the APM service
DisplayString.Description: The APM DataSource is unable to communicate with the APM service. The error message is {0}.

DisplayString.Name: APM Client-Side Monitoring Configuration
DisplayString.Description: This monitor verifies that an APM Agent has been correctly processing APM Client-Side Monitoring configuration. The monitor turns to Warning state when an invalid configuration or a configuration conflict is detected.

DisplayString.Name: APM Client-Side Monitoring Configuration Error or Conflict
DisplayString.Description: The APM Agent has encountered an error while processing APM Client-Side Monitoring configuration. This could be caused by an agent problem or by incorrect or conflicting configuration specified in multiple templates.

DisplayString.Name: Unsupported APM event received from an agent
DisplayString.Description: This monitor detects when unsupported APM events were received from an agent. The monitor turns into a warning state when this occurs.

DisplayString.Name: Monitor detected unsupported APM events were received from an agent
Unsupported APM event received from an agent
DisplayString.Description: Operations Manager is able to process APM events from the version of Microsoft Monitoring Agent included in the same release. If a newer release agent submits APM events to an older management server, the server might not process such events and the events will then be discarded.

DisplayString.Name: IIS Application Pools Recycle Required
DisplayString.Description: This monitor tracks the need to recycle IIS application pools due to a change in monitoring settings for applications running on the web server.

DisplayString.Name: IIS Application Pools recycle not required
IIS Application Pools recycle is required
IIS Application Pools recycle is required
DisplayString.Description: Application monitoring settings on server {0} have been modified. In order for the new settings to be applied, you need to recycle IIS application pools on that server. Until IIS application pools are recycled, the new monitoring settings will not be applied. The monitored applications however will continue to function properly. If an "IIS Restart is required" alert is present for the same server, you can ignore this alert and just follow the knowledge in the "IIS Restart is required" alert. Once you restart IIS, the "IIS Application Pools recycle is required" alert will be auto-resolved.

DisplayString.Name: IIS Restart is required
DisplayString.Description: This monitor tracks the need to restart IIS due to a change in monitoring settings for applications running on the web server.

DisplayString.Name: IIS Restart is required
DisplayString.Description: Application monitoring settings on server {0} have been modified. In order for the new settings to be applied, you need to restart IIS on that server. Until IIS is restarted, the new monitoring settings will not be applied. The monitored applications however will continue to function properly.

DisplayString.Name: Service Running State
DisplayString.Description: Monitors the current status of the APM Windows service. An alert from this monitor indicates the APM service is not currently running

DisplayString.Name: Service is not running
DisplayString.Description: Service is not running

DisplayString.Name: Service is running
DisplayString.Description: Service is running

DisplayString.Name: APM Windows service stopped
DisplayString.Description: The '{0}' service on computer {1} has stopped running

DisplayString.Name: APM Write Action Availability
DisplayString.Description: This monitor verifies that the APM Write Actions are successfully storing events in the Operations Database. The monitor turns to a warning state when an APM Event fails to be submitted to the database, and resets to Healthy when insertion resumes.

DisplayString.Name: APM Write Action Failed to Submit an Event to the Database
DisplayString.Description: The APM Write Action had an error while submitting events to the database.

DisplayString.Name: AVIcode Intercept Service Found Monitor Type
Collect APM Agent Windows Events
DisplayString.Description: This rule collects all APM Agent events for troubleshooting purposes.

DisplayString.Name: Collect .NET CSM Collector/% Invalid Tokens/sec
DisplayString.Description: This rule collects the rate of invalid monitoring requests rejected by the client-side monitoring collection endpoint. The values are obtained from .NET CSM Collector % Invalid Tokens/sec performance counter.

DisplayString.Name: Client-side monitoring collection endpoint alerting rule for IIS Shared Configuration
DisplayString.Description: This rule generates an alert when an event log contains a warning that suggests that a client-side monitoring collection endpoint might no longer be needed.

DisplayString.Name: Client-side monitoring collection IIS endpoint is not removed
DisplayString.Description: Disabling monitoring for {0} on website {1} did not remove the client-side monitoring collection IIS endpoint CSMCollector due to shared IIS configuration. If this endpoint is no longer used by other monitored servers, remove it from the shared IIS configuration using IIS management tools.

DisplayString.Name: Collect .NET CSM Collector/% Unsynchronized Tokens/sec
DisplayString.Description: This rule collects the rate of client-side monitoring requests with invalid or expired timestamps. These requests are rejected by the client-side monitoring collection endpoint. The values collected by this rule are obtained from .NET CSM Collector % Unsynchronized Tokens/sec performance counter.

DisplayString.Name: Collect System Center Management APM Service Process Handles Count
DisplayString.Description: This rule collects Process \ Handle Count counter for System Center Management APM Service Process

DisplayString.Name: Collect System Center Management APM Service Process Private Bytes
DisplayString.Description: This rule collects Process \ Private Bytes counter for System Center Management APM Service Process

DisplayString.Name: Collect System Center Management APM Service Process % Processor time
DisplayString.Description: This rule collects Process \ % Processor time counter for System Center Management APM Service Process

DisplayString.Name: Recycle Application Pools
DisplayString.Description: This task recycles Application Pools on target computers.

DisplayString.Name: Restart Internet Information Services
DisplayString.Description: This task restarts Internet Information Services on target computers.

DisplayString.Name: Restart APM Service
DisplayString.Description: This task restarts the System Center Management APM service on the target Agent.

DisplayString.Name: Rejected Client-Side Monitoring Requests
DisplayString.Description: This view shows the rate of the monitoring requests that are rejected by client-side monitoring collection endpoint. These requests are rejected because they are not properly encrypted or do not comply with the required format of the monitoring data.

DisplayString.Name: Active Alerts
DisplayString.Description: Activated APM Agent Active Alerts

DisplayString.Name: Operations Manager APM Infrastructure Monitoring
DisplayString.Description: Operations Manager APM Infrastructure Monitoring

DisplayString.Name: APM Agent State
DisplayString.Description: Activated APM Agent State

DisplayString.Name: All Events
DisplayString.Description: Activated APM Agent Events

DisplayString.Name: All Performance Data
DisplayString.Description: Activated APM Agent Performance

DisplayString.Name: IIS Restart / Recycle Required
DisplayString.Description: APM Agent IIS restart / recycle required

DisplayString.Name: Handle Count
DisplayString.Description: APM Agent Performance

DisplayString.Name: % Processor Time
DisplayString.Description: APM Agent Performance

DisplayString.Name: Private Bytes
DisplayString.Description: APM Agent Performance

DisplayString.Name: IIS Restart
DisplayString.Description: APM Agent Alerts

DisplayString.Name: IIS Recycle
DisplayString.Description: APM Agent Alerts

DisplayString.Name: APM Agent Details
DisplayString.Description: APM Agent Root Folder

DisplayString.Name: Generate alert by event severity write action
DisplayString.Description: Generate alert by event severity write action

section.title: Summary
section.para: The instance state becomes unhealthy when the APM .NET Configuration is invalid or conflicting.

section.title: Causes
section.para: APM configuration infrastructure generates configuration for the APM .NET monitoring agent based on the settings specified in the .NET Application Performance Monitoring template, management packs, and a number of files containing default configuration directives that are pre-installed with the agent. During this process, there could be errors depending on agent problems or conflicting settings, which will prevent configuration from being successfully loaded and used.

Reasons for this might include: an incompatible profiler is installed side-by-side with Microsoft Monitoring Agent, wrong settings specified during configuration, conflicting settings for the same application specified in two or more templates, or agent installation is damaged and needs a repair.
The most common cause for this type of error is a configuration conflict. For example, multiple templates specifying conflicting settings for the same application or application pool.

APM monitoring is applied to processes and only one configuration can be applied to any specific process. If you are configuring monitoring for different applications hosted in the same process, global configuration settings, such as namespaces, exception tracking, and exception handlers, must be the same for all monitored applications in the process. With IIS, all web applications that are running in the same application pool (w3wp.exe process) must have the same configuration for namespaces, exception handlers, and exception tracking.
Unless the configuration conflict is corrected, application performance monitoring will be disabled on this server the next time the application pools recycle.

section.title: Resolutions
section.para: Check the Alert Context and the Operations Manager Event Log on failing instance to get additional details about the cause of the problem.
If there is an incompatible profiler installed side-by-side with Microsoft Monitoring Agent, you may need to uninstall or turn it off in order to begin monitoring your application with .NET APM.

If the problem is in the conflicting configuration the event log might contain multiple messages for a single conflict or error, and it will help you isolate the application groups that are causing the configuration conflicts on the agent.

Using the information provided in the error(s), ensure that the namespaces, exception handlers and exception tracking has been configured the same across each specified application group. To update the application group configuration:

listItem.para: Open the Operations Console.
Go to the Authoring space.
Expand Management Pack Templates.
Select .NET Application Performance Monitoring.
Select the first conflicting template instance and click properties in the Task pane.

section.para: Using the properties wizard, you can adjust the conflicting settings in the application groups.

section.title: Summary
section.para: The instance state becomes unhealthy when the APM .NET objects that are required for configuration can’t be written by the Management Server.

section.title: Causes
section.para: APM configuration infrastructure creates object instances that are required for configuration of the APM .NET monitoring agents, based on the settings specified in the .NET Application Performance Monitoring template. During this process, there could be errors depending on server problems or conflicting settings, which will prevent the objects from being successfully discovered. The most common cause for this type of error is a configuration conflict is that the Internet Information Services management pack has been removed after APM had already been configured.

section.title: Resolutions
section.para: Check the Alert Context and the Operations Manager Event Log on the server to understand more about the exact type of conflict or error. The event log might contain multiple messages for a single conflict or error. They should be investigated. In case the IIS Management Pack has been removed, you would need to import it again. Several other errors might require escalation to Microsoft Technical Support.

section.title: Summary
section.para: The instance state becomes unhealthy if AVIcode .NET Enterprise Agent is found on a computer that was already running the System Center Operations Manager APM service. Although the push installation of the AVIcode agent to a System Center Operations Manager agent (Microsoft Monitoring Agent) will be prevented, this situation can still happen through manual installations.

section.title: Causes
section.para: The AVIcode .NET Enterprise Agent has been found on a computer where Operations Manager APM Agent had previously been deployed. Operations Manager AMP functionality replaces the ASP.NET Application Library MP for web applications and services hosted on IIS 7 and above. To use Operations Manager APM, you must remove the AVIcode interceptors from the target server and then reinstall the Operations Manager Agent. To use AVIcode interceptors, install the Operations Manager agent without APM. The two agents cannot co-exist.

section.title: Resolutions
section.para: To resolve this issue, you might need to decide which agent you intend to use:

listItem.para: If you want to keep using the APM functionality and AVIcode was installed by mistake, the AVIcode interceptors must be removed from the target system, and the Operations Manager agent must be repaired.
To remove AVIcode 5.x from the system:
Log onto the system.
Go to Start->All Programs->AVIcode Intercept Studio.
Launch Intercept Management console.
Delete all monitored applications through the console.
Recycle IIS to unload the interceptor.
Close the console.
Go to Control Panel -> Programs -> Uninstall a Program.
Uninstall AVIcode Intercept Agent if it is present.
Uninstall AVIcode Integration Kit for Operations Manager 2007 if it is present.
Uninstall AVIcode System Center LobMapper for .NET Enterprise Management Pack if it is present.
Reinstall/Repair the Operations Manager Agent.
To remove ASP.NET Applications Library:
Launch the Operations Manager Console
Go to the Monitoring space -> ASP.NET Application -> ASP.NET Application State View and note which applications are being monitored on the target system.
Go to the Monitoring space -> ASP.NET Web Service -> Web Service State View and note which web services are being monitored on the target system.
Go to the Authoring space -> Management Pack Templates -> ASP.NET Application.
Delete the templates corresponding to the applications noted in step 2.
Go to the Authoring Space –> Management Pack Templates -> ASP.NET Web Service.
Delete the templates corresponding to the web services noted in step 3.
Log onto the target system.
Go to Control Panel -> Programs -> Uninstall a Program.
Uninstall System Center Operations Manager 2007 R2 ASP.NET monitoring if it is present.
Reinstall/Repair the Operations Manager Agent.

If you want to install AVIcode agent, the APM service can be removed by re-installing the System Center Operations Manager agent manually and specifying the command line parameter /NOAPM=1. This will stop the APM service from being installed and allow the AVIcode agent to be deployed to the host.
To remove AVIcode 5.x from the system:
Log onto the system.
Go to Start->All Programs->AVIcode Intercept Studio.
Launch Intercept Management Console.
Delete all monitored applications through the console.
Recycle IIS to unload the interceptor.
Close the console.
Go to Control Panel -> Programs -> Uninstall a Program.
Uninstall AVIcode Intercept Agent if it is present.
Uninstall AVIcode Integration Kit for Operations Manager 2007 if it is present.
Uninstall AVIcode System Center LobMapper for .NET Enterprise Management Pack if it is present.
To repair the System Center Operations Manager agent (Microsoft Monitoring Agent) by removing the APM agent manually:
Copy the MOMAgent.msi from the System Center Operations Manager media or Management Server to the agent that was pre-installed with APM.
Launch an elevated command prompt.
Run the agent installation using the following command line:
Select option “Repair”.
After the APM agent has been removed, you can now re-install the AVIcode 5.7 agent.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The instance state becomes unhealthy when the APM DataSource fails to connect to the APM Windows service.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Workflows working with APM Data rely on the APM DataSource being able to connect to the Systems Center Management APM Windows service in order to retrieve this data. The service must be running for .NET Monitoring to collect data from applications running on the server. It may have been stopped or disabled or could be not responding. Another reason for this could be that the agent installation is damaged and should be repaired. It could also be a transient condition.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Connect to the server where the service has been stopped and use Services.msc to restart the System Center Management APM Windows service. If the service fails to restart, check the Operations Manager event log for errors related to the service.

section.title: Summary
section.para: The instance state becomes unhealthy when the APM .NET Client Side monitoring Configuration is invalid or conflicting.

section.title: Causes
section.para: APM configuration infrastructure generates configuration for the APM .NET Client-Side Monitoring agent based on the settings specified in the .NET Application Performance Monitoring template, management packs, and a number of files containing default configuration directives that are pre-installed with the agent. During this process, there could be errors depending on agent problems or conflicting settings, which will prevent configuration from being successfully loaded and used. Reasons for this include: wrong settings specified during the configuration process, conflicting settings for the same application specified in different templates, or even the agent installation being damaged and needing to be repaired.
The most common cause for this type of error is a configuration conflict, for example: multiple templates specifying conflicting settings for the same application.

APM client-side monitoring is applied per website and only one configuration can be applied to any specific website. If you are configuring monitoring for different applications hosted in the same website, some configuration settings must be the same for all monitored applications in the process, as they will be sharing a single Client-Side Monitoring (CSM) Collector.
In some cases, an error of this type can also be caused by a broken encryption key.
Unless the configuration conflict is corrected, client-side application performance monitoring will not work as expected for this website.

section.title: Resolutions
section.para: Check the Alert Context and the Operations Manager Event Log on this agent to get additional details about the cause of the conflict. The event log might contain multiple messages for a single conflict or error, and it will help you isolate the application groups that are causing the configuration conflicts on the agent.

Using the information provided in the error(s), ensure that the thresholds and other settings have been configured the same across each specified application group. To update the application group configuration:

listItem.para: Open the Operations Console.
Go to the Authoring space.
Expand Management Pack Templates.
Select .NET Application Performance Monitoring.
Select the first conflicting template instance and click properties in the Task pane.

section.para: Using the properties wizard you can adjust the conflicting settings in the application groups.

In the case of a broken RunAs account, it is sufficient to just open the .NET Application Performance Monitoring template and save it again so that all the settings, together with the RunAs Account, are written again in the correct format.

section.title: Summary
section.para: The instance state becomes unhealthy when unsupported APM events are received.

section.title: Causes
section.para: Operations Manager is able to process APM events from the version of Microsoft Monitoring Agents included in the same release. If a newer release agent submits APM events to an older management server, the server might not process such events and the events will then be discarded.

section.title: Resolutions
section.para: You must upgrade the management server and web console to a version compatible with all agents in your management group in order to view APM events received from all agents.
Review the System Center release notes and the Microsoft Monitoring Agent release notes to learn more about versioning and compatibility.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor tracks the need to recycle IIS application pools caused by a change in monitoring settings for applications running on the web server. This monitor transitions to an unhealthy state when IIS application pools need to be recycled.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When application monitoring settings are modified using the .NET Application Performance Monitoring template, IIS application pools might need to be recycled for the new settings to take effect. One example of a scenario that requires recycling of IIS application pools is enabling client-side monitoring.

maml:listItem.maml:para: If an "IIS Restart is required" alert is present for the same server, you can ignore this alert and just follow the knowledge in the "IIS Restart is required" alert. Once you restart IIS, the "IIS Application Pools recycle is required" alert will be resolved automatically.
You can recycle all of IIS application pools by clicking the following link: Recycle IIS application pools
Note that clicking the above link restarts all application pools.
Alternatively, you can use Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager to recycle the application pools directly on the web server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor tracks the need to restart IIS due to a change in monitoring settings for applications running on the web server. This monitor transitions to an unhealthy state when IIS needs to be recycled.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When application monitoring settings are modified using the .NET Application Performance Monitoring template, IIS might need to be restarted for the new settings to take effect. An example of a scenario that requires restarting IIS is when you are configuring .NET application monitoring for the first application on the web server.

maml:listItem.maml:para: You can restart IIS by clicking the following link: Restart IIS
You can run the iisreset.exe command on the web server.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: The instance state becomes unhealthy when APM Windows service is not running

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The Systems Center Management APM Windows service must be running for .NET Application Performance Monitoring to collect data from applications running on the server. It might have been stopped or disabled.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Connect to the server where the service has been stopped and use Services.msc to restart the System Center Management APM Windows service.
If the service fails to restart, check the Operations Manager event log for errors related to the service.

section.title: Summary
section.para: The instance state becomes unhealthy when an error is detected on the Management Server when writing APM Events into the Operations Database.

section.title: Causes
section.para: Typically, this depends on availability of the database, its load, and the general load on the system. It could be a transient condition in which the monitor resets to the healthy state.

section.title: Resolutions
section.para: Verify that the Operations Database is up and running.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects the rate of invalid monitoring requests rejected by the client-side monitoring collection endpoint. The values collected by this rule are obtained from .NET CSM Collector % Invalid Tokens/sec performance counter.

The client-side monitoring collection IIS endpoint CSMCollector rejects all requests that are not properly encrypted or do not comply with the required format of received data. A high rate of invalid client-side monitoring requests might indicate a problem with client-side monitoring security settings. Additionally, improper configuration of the load balancer, when CSMCollector receives monitoring requests for the web pages rendered by the web servers monitored in a different Operations Manager management group, could cause a high rate of invalid client-side monitoring requests. Invalid synthetic transactions that are running against CSMCollector IIS endpoint result in an increased rated of invalid client-side monitoring requests.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Turning off client-side monitoring in IIS Shared Configuration environments preserves the client-side monitoring collection IIS endpoint CSMCollector, which might be used by other monitored servers.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: When you enable client-side monitoring, a single instance of CSMCollector is created automatically for each website that hosts at least one client-side monitored application. This endpoint is not needed for server-side monitoring or when monitoring is disabled. You can manually delete unused instances of CSMCollector with Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager. Turning off client-side monitoring automatically deletes the CSMCollector endpoint in environments that do not use IIS Shared Configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Ensure that no servers sharing the same IIS configuration host applications that are monitored with client-side monitoring on the website specified by this alert:

maml:listItem.maml:para: If client-side monitoring is enabled for any application, keep the CSMCollector endpoint.
If no remaining applications have client-side monitoring enabled, you can manually delete unused instances of CSMCollector using Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager.

maml:section.maml:para: You can close this alert after ensuring that there are no unwanted instances of client-side monitoring collection endpoints configured in the IIS Shared Configuration.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This rule collects the rate of client-side monitoring requests with invalid or expired timestamps. These requests are rejected by the client-side monitoring collection endpoint. The values collected by this rule are obtained from .NET CSM Collector % Unsynchronized Tokens/sec performance counter.

The client-side monitoring collection IIS endpoint CSMCollector rejects all requests that have invalid or expired timestamps. An increased rate of requests with expired timestamps usually indicates that the clocks are not properly synchronized among the web servers in a web farm environment. Additionally, an increased rate of requests with invalid or expired timestamps might occur with incorrectly configured synthetic transactions that are running against CSMCollector.
